Authors:
Daniela Goffre, Annette Bruun Jensen, Claudia C. López
Lastra, Richard Alan Humber, Patricia Julia Folgarait
Title:
Conidiobolus lunula (Entomophthoromycota:
Entomophthoromycetes), a new species isolated from leafcutter ants.
Keywords:
entomopathogen, Entomophthoromycetes, Entomophthoromycota,
social insects, villose conidia, 1 new taxon
Abstract:
Entomophthoralean fungi with entomopathogenic abilities to
infect social insects are rare. Here we described a fungus isolated from
leafcutter ants (LCA). Morphologically, this fungus has spherical
primary conidia, and we described two types of microconidia: one with
the same shape as the primary conidia, and another with an elliptical to
half-moon shape. It also produces villose conidia, as was only known
previously for Conidiobolus coronatus. A multi-locus phylogenetic
analysis was performed with the amplified sequences of three regions
(nuclear large subunit ribosomal DNA or nuc 28S rDNA; nuclear small
subunit ribosomal RNA or nuc 18S rDNA; and nuc rDNA ITS1‐5.8S‐ITS2 (ITS
barcode)), using a Basidiobolus strain as outgroup. Our isolates are
distinguished as a new species with a bootstrap support of 100% and are
more closely related to C. brefeldianus than to C. coronatus, despite
its greater morphological resemblance with the latter. We describe a new
species, C. lunula, based on morphological differences, its phylogenetic
distinctness from the previously described species, and its isolation
from an altogether new host. This is the first finding of an
entomophthoralean species isolated from LCA.
